sub_topic: Finding the maximum flow in a network.
message_1:
Consider the following network:

![Network diagram](https://i.imgur.com/LgsZql1.png)

Each edge in the network has a capacity, which indicates how much flow can pass through it. The goal is to find the maximum flow that can be sent from node A to node H.

Using the Ford-Fulkerson algorithm, find the maximum flow in the network and show the flow path with its corresponding flow values.
message_2:
To find the maximum flow in the network using the Ford-Fulkerson algorithm, we will iteratively find augmenting paths from the source (node A) to the sink (node H) and update the residual capacities of the edges. We will continue this process until there are no more augmenting paths left.

Step 1: Initialize flow in all edges to 0.

Step 2: Find an augmenting path from A to H using DFS or BFS. We will use DFS in this example.

1st Augmenting Path: A -> B -> E -> H
Flow in this path: min(10, 8, 10) = 8
Update the residual capacities of the edges in the path.

2nd Augmenting Path: A -> B -> D -> F -> H
Flow in this path: min(2, 10, 9, 10) = 2
Update the residual capacities of the edges in the path.

3rd Augmenting Path: A -> C -> D -> F -> H
Flow in this path: min(10, 6, 7, 8) = 6
Update the residual capacities of the edges in the path.

4th Augmenting Path: A -> C -> G -> H
Flow in this path: min(4, 4, 4) = 4
Update the residual capacities of the edges in the path.

Now, there are no more augmenting paths left from A to H.

The maximum flow in the network is the sum of the flows in the augmenting paths: 8 + 2 + 6 + 4 = 20.

The flow path with its corresponding flow values is as follows:

A -> B -> E -> H: 8
A -> B -> D -> F -> H: 2
A -> C -> D -> F -> H: 6
A -> C -> G -> H: 4
